# Ridgeline plots {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-tip appearance='simple' icon=false} ***This graph is largely complete and just needs final proof reading.*** ::: :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #02577A;"} Graph info :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ridgeline_plots_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a categorical variable** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** ::: :::: ## Description If we want to plot density curves but retain the interpretability of the axes, consider comparing multiple distributions using the [`ggridges` package](https://wilkelab.org/ggridges/). ## Set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by allison horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Remove missing `island` from `penguins` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} peng_ridges <- filter(penguins, !is.na(island)) glimpse(peng_ridges) #> Rows: 344 #> Columns: 8 #> $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, … #> $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen,… #> $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3… #> $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6… #> $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181… #> $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650… #> $ sex male, female, female, NA, female… #> $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 20… ``` ::: ::: :::: ## Grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` Map `bill_length_mm` to the `x` axis Map `island` to the `y` axis and `fill` Add the `ggridges::geom_density_ridges()` layer (with `alpha` set to `2/3`) Remove the legend with `show.legend = FALSE` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_ridges <- labs( title = "Adult foraging penguins", x = "Bill length (millimeters)", y = "Island", fill = "Island") ggp2_ridges <- ggplot(data = peng_ridges, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = island, fill = island)) + ggridges::geom_density_ridges(alpha = 2/3, show.legend = FALSE) ggp2_ridges + labs_ridges ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Ridgeline plots are excellent for comparing continuous distributions across groups. ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ridgeline_plots_files/figure-html/create_graph_ridges-1.png){width=100% height=100%} ::: ::: ::::
